div.head: First Impressions of Venice
div.p: October 9th, 1835. Nothing that I had read, nothing that I had imagined, could have prepared me for the reality of Venice. The city rose from the water as if conjured by some enchantment, her palaces and churches reflected in the still surface of the lagoon with a perfection that seemed to double every beauty.

We approached by gondola, and as we turned into the Grand Canal, the Ducal Palace came into view. Its arcade of pointed arches, resting upon columns of Istrian stone, presented a harmony of proportion that I had never before witnessed in any building. The upper wall, clad in a pattern of pink and grey rose and pearl-white marble, caught the afternoon light in a manner that defied description.

div.head: The Mosaics of St. Mark’s
div.p: The Basilica of St. Mark is unlike any church in England. Where our cathedrals achieve their effect through height and the aspiration of the Gothic pointed arch, St. Mark’s achieves its power through colour and surface. Every wall, every vault, every dome is covered with mosaic of gold and glass, depicting the stories of Scripture with a vividness that no stained glass window could equal.

I observed with particular interest the capitelli of the exterior columns. Ruskin's detailed study of Venetian column capitals would later form a major section of The Stones of Venice (1851–1853). Each capital told its own story in carved stone: here a scene of the months and their labours, there the virtues and vices arrayed in allegorical combat. The craftsmanship was of the highest order, yet bore the marks of individual hands rather than mechanical reproduction.

lg.l: A city built upon the waters deep,
Where marble walls embrace the rising tide,
And ancient stones their solemn vigil keep
O’er glories that the centuries cannot hide.

div.p: The colourcolour of the stone, particularly in the late afternoon, transforms from white to the warmest gold, as if the building itself were alive to the passage of the sun. I made three separate watercolour studies attempting to fix this effect, but the medium proved entirely wholly inadequate to the task.
